body: Still need to double check that Amazon actually works with this style of sending the token, will do that in a moment.

And I'm not really sure how to fix it, so I'd appreciate any guidance you have on that.

@Kami  OK, I think the fix for the test failure is:
cp docs/compute/drivers/index.rst docs/loadbalancer/drivers/.

In docs/loadbalancer/drivers/index.rst:
s/Compute/Load Balancer/

Does that seem right to you?

This changes gives significant speed improvements (upwards of a whole second) when your application server and cloudfiles are in the same region/datacenter.

It should match with a first argument, but currently it's matching with an open parenthesis.

closing, will open a new pull request for the second issue only

With the latest version (0.14.0) you can specify auth URL in two forms:
1. Full URL including a path (e.g. `https://192.168.1.101:5000/v2.0/tokens/`)
2. Just a base URL without a path (e.g. `https://192.168.1.101:5000`)

It looks like the problem in this case is that the existing URL specifies just a partial path. Is this indeed the case?

If it is, I would prefer to be explicit and specify a full URL with a path (first example).
This has been the case indeed

Looks good.

Patch merged into trunk, thanks.
References https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-503

I'm actually not too sure about this change. There were quite a lot of talks about caching in general in the past. Usually the consensus was that we want to avoid doing it in the Libcloud and leave it up to the user.

The reason for that is that doing caching correctly and in a robust manner is hard and has all kinds of consequences (invalidation, etc.).

On top of that, if we decided to do it we should be consistent and the same change for `get_object_cdn_url` and in all other drives.

Because of the complexities involved, I'd rather avoid doing it all together like I said above.

This change is unnecessary.

If you know the container name, you can manually instantiate the `Container` class and use that - https://libcloud.readthedocs.org/en/latest/other/working-with-oo-apis.html

How is the user supposed to cache the CDN's URL (which really ought not to change over the in-memory life of the instance of a single object here) and continue to use libcloud as an abstraction layer?

I was watching network traffic while using libcloud and saw 3 HTTP requests for one single "get_object" call. Two were about getting the container, and one was the object. If you're getting multiple objects, as through a storage layer, this is going to be very slow.

I was actually thinking about that in the past.

If we want to make it consistent across all the drivers, each value should be exposed as a separate record (that's how it currently works with other drivers).

For example:
- record 1: name=None, value=ASPMX.L.GOOGLE.COM., extra['priority']=1
- record 2:  name=None, value=ALT1.ASPMX.L.GOOGLE.COM., extra['priority']=5
- etc.
Gotcha, that makes sense. I'll update this shortly.

In any case, the patch looks good so I've merged it into trunk.

Thanks!

Do you agree with the changes in commit 8874914 (omitting coding style :) ? This approach would allow the Eucalyptus and Nimbus drivers to pass additional params to the EC2 driver, while maintaining the same interface.

The only issue that I'm afraid of, is that it could be abused at some point.

@mneagul Yeah, I hate some of our legacy code and `**kwargs` abuse which happens there.

I would actually do the following which is more robust and less error prone:
1. Explicitly define `create_node` method with all the arguments in the EC2 and Eucalyptus NodeDriver class
2. Add "private" `_create_node` method to the base class. This method is called by `create_node` in the EC2 and Eucalyptus node driver class. This method does all the work and can take `params` (or similar argument) which differs between EC2 and Eucalyptus driver.

I've merged changes to trunk, thanks.

While I was at it, I also made some changes to parse / handle SRV records better.
Ah great call, thanks!

I went ahead and merged this pull request with my changes into trunk.

Thanks!
@mneagul Bump. Let me know if you need any help.

We've discussed this on the IRC with @cderamus yesterday.

I think we should also map `stopping` and `expunging` to `pending` instead of `terminated`. The reason for that is that not all the operations are available until the node is fully stopped (`stopped` state).

This means that currently your code might fail if you wait until node.state == stopped because node might actually still be in stopping state.

I've merged the changes mentioned above and merged this into trunk.

Thanks.
Merged into trunk, thanks.

Looks good. Changes merged into trunk.

Honestly, I don't think this approach is that bad.
Having trouble making DummyFileObject actually behave like a file object. The dummy provider in general seems a bit unfinished, am I better off not using it?

I need to have a more closer look, but IIRC, this class is only used in the dummy driver. There is also a `DummyIterator` class which is used in some tests.

As far as the completeness goes, it should be more or less complete, but it's a Dummy driver so there aren't really a tons of use cases for it. What kind of problems are you having exactly?

I believe that in the beginning, dummy drives were added for demonstration pruposed. Another use case I imagined a while back is building an online REPL where users can play with dummy drivers.
I'm trying to write unit tests for something that uses libcloud and I was hoping the dummy driver would make that relatively easy as an in-memory backend that otherwise gives mostly the same API.
It sounds like maybe I'm fixing this at the wrong level and DummyDriver should just be overhauled a bit to fit the bill of "simple in-memory backend", does that seem reasonable?
It is already most of the way there, just need to remove a bunch of usage of DummyFileObject in favor of returning real data.
@coderanger Yeah, this sound good. And it would also be good to implement methods posted above by @Jc2k

You don't have an AWS account? Or is it something else?

To make this useful, we also need to implement `SetLoadBalancerPoliciesOfListener` method (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/APIReference/API_SetLoadBalancerPoliciesOfListener.html).

This method actually applies a policy to the load balancer.

From the article:

```
elb-create-lb-policy  myELBName        \
  --policy-type SSLNegotiationPolicyType \
  --policy-name=mySSLPolicyName        \
  --attribute "name=Reference-Security-Policy, value=ELBSecurityPolicy-2014-01"

$ elb-set-lb-policies-of-listener  myELBName \
  --lb-port 443 \
  --policy-names mySSLPolicyName,[PolicyName2,...]
```

@Kami  Thanks I will make the required changes.
